DOC.HEAD: National Minute of Peace Marred by Violence
Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with extension of emergency regulations, details, minor editing. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of beleaguered Peruvians prayed for peace Friday during a national minute of silence called by church and government officials, but even that brief moment was marred by violence. The same day, the government renewed emergency regulations for 60 days in eight departments and one province. Such regulations have been used since 1982 to combat terrorism. Precisely at noon Friday, traffic stopped, factories became quiet, and people paused for a moment of reflection as one of the most violent years in the country's history came to a close. Hundreds gathered in Lima's main square to hear an address by Cardinal Juan Landazuri, but as the minute of silence began a small group of striking state workers clashed with riot police in the middle of the square. Witnesses said police quickly surrounded the group of about 10 workers, beat them with riot clubs and hauled them away. As the minute of silence ended, church bells rang and horns blared as motorists showed their support for the vigil, the third consecutive year the minute of prayer has been observed. Peru is being wracked by a leftist insurgency that has taken more than 17,000 lives since 1980. At least 2,500 people have disappeared. Sen. Enrique Bernales, head of a special commission on violence, said this week that nearly 3,000 people have been killed in political violence this year. ``Ten years of violence, of terrorism, of destruction and of death have painfully torn apart the heart of our people,'' Landazuri said. Witnesses said traffic proceeded normally in outlying suburbs of the capital, as many people ignored the call to prayer. The government announced the extension of emergency rules in a decree published in the official gazette, El Peruano. The state of emergency regulations gives broad powers to the military to fight leftist insurgents and suspends some civil liberties, including freedom of movement and guarantees against search and seizure. Such restrictions cover about one-third of this Andean nation, affecting more than half its 21 million residents.
